Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on . Due
to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager Rorie Dodge-Pifer at (517) 899-6024.
Sincerely,
Jennifer Pastorick, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4113-1-i Employee records.
• (1)An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in
this rule:
• (i) Documentation from the Michigan
department of human services, the
equivalent state or Canadian provincial

agency, or equivalent agency in the
country where the person usually resides,
that the person has not been determined
to be a perpetrator of child abuse or child
neglect. The documentation shall be
completed not more than 30 days prior to
the start of employment and every 12
months thereafter.
One of fourteen new employee files reviewed lacked documentation of central
registry being completed within thirty days of hire as the central registry clearance
was obtained 35 days prior to hire.
CCI Rule 400.4113-1-j Employee records.
• (1)An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in
this rule:
• (j) A written evaluation of the employee's
performance within 30 days of the
completion of the probationary period or
within 180 days, whichever is less, and a
written evaluation of the employee's
performance annually thereafter.
One of four new employee files reviewed that required an evaluation lacked the
employee's evaluation.
CCI Rule 400.4166-1-a Discharge plan
• (1) When a resident is discharged from
institutional care, all of the following information
shall be documented in the case record within
14 days after discharge:
• (a) The date of and reason for discharge,
and the new location of the child.
• (b) A brief summary or other
documentation of the services provided
while in residence, including medical and
dental services.
• (c) An assessment of the resident's needs
that remain to be met.
• (d) Any services that will be provided by
the facility after discharge.

• (e) A statement that the discharge plan
recommendations, including medical and
dental follow up that is needed, have
been reviewed with the resident and with
the parent and with the responsible case
manager.
• (f) The name and official title of the
person to whom the resident was
discharged.
One of four discharged youth files reviewed lacked a discharge plan.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Technical assistance was provided regarding CCI Rule 400.4133-1-e to ensure
references are completed prior to hire as one employee had references dated
the same date of hire however the references were time stamped indicating
they were received in the early morning hours prior to the employee starting.
Provided technical assistance that the hire date be the date after references
are received.
• Technical assistance was provided regarding the fire inspection which noted
easily ignited or rapidly burning combustible decorations are not permitted in a
facility. Personal artwork and personal decorations made or owned by
residents are permitted up to 20% of wall space in each room or use areas
other than means of egress and hazardous areas if they have been treated
with fire retardant materials approved by Underwriters Laboratory. In the
classroom the cardboard lizard needs to be removed from the ceiling.
• Technical assistance was provided regarding Initial Treatment Plans and
Updated Treatment Plans as the facility has all the information required per the
rules however not in one report as the facility completes reports more
frequently than the rule requirements.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was provided regarding the Bureau of Fire Services process as
the facility is remodeling and is looking into moving to key swipe doors.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care

There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
• Interim 2024: Corrective Action Plan was recorded during this reporting
period as a result of the Interim inspection completed 9/20/202. This
CAP contained two violations of CCI Rule 400.4113 regarding
references missing and Central Registry Clearances not being
completed prior to hire, one violation for CCI Rule 400.4128 regarding a
written training plan for the Music coordinator position, and CCI Rule
400.4116 regarding the Chief Administrator not following licensing rules.
The facility implemented a CAP regarding files being reviewed to ensure
all documentation required is received prior to the position being offered
to an employee, created a written training plan for the Music Coordinator
position to ensure the staff had the required yearly training hours, and
Chief Administrator set action steps to ensure licensing rules regarding
Central Registry Clearance being completed prior to hire was followed.
The facility was found to be in compliance with all staff having central
registry clearances completed prior to hire however during the renewal
inspection it was found one employee clearance was outside the thirty
days of hire as it was thirty-five days.
• Special Investigation 2025SIC0000742 with CAP approval date of
7/21/2025 was a result of violations for CCI Rule 400.4127 regarding
varying interval checks not being completed and PA 116 regarding
falsification of documentation. The facility implemented a CAP to update
the facilities internal policy and procedure, retrained staff, and
implemented action steps to verify the varying interval checks are being
completed and consistent with documentation via reviewing video
footage. The agency is currently complying with the CAP action steps,
and DCWL continues to monitor CAP compliance with no noted
concerns.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget and the agency's financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A

Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment was reviewed. Chief Administrator reported
since the last reporting period, the facility has experienced a staffing crisis which
lasted from last summer to the fall which led to the facility questing the future of the
facility and program. The facility has experienced a lot of staff turnover during the
last year and a half which the facility found having their new hiring process in place
has been helpful to ensure all the documentation needed in the employee file is
obtained prior to hire. Chief Administrator reported supervisors and Administration
will continue to evaluate the effectiveness of the current CAP’s and work with
current and new staff on implementation.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff reported they feel supported by leadership and are provided with the training
needed to complete the responsibilities of their position. Staff reported the youth
are well cared for at the facility and provided with tools to be successful in their
recovery. Staff reported the facility has good communication.
Youth interviews were conducted during the onsite inspection. All youth reported
feeling safe and well cared for at the facility. All youth reported the staff are
supportive and treat youth with dignity and respect. There were no concerns noted
by any youth during interviews.
Description of Agency Walk Through
An onsite inspection and walkthrough of the facility occurred on September 2,
2025. There were no issues or safety concerns noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
